In [[biology]], '''reciprocal causation''' arises when developing organisms are both ''products'' of [[evolution]] as well as ''causes'' of evolution.{{cite book|last1=Levins|first1=R|last2=Lewontin|first2=R|title=The Dialectical Biologist|date=1985|publisher=Aakar books}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Oyama|editor1-first=S|editor2-last=Griffiths|editor2-first=PE|editor3-last=Gray|editor3-first=RD|title=Cycles of Contingency: Developmental Systems and Evolution|date=2001|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, USA}}{{cite book|last1=West-Eberhard|first1=MJ|title=Developmental Plasticity and Evolution|date=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford}}{{cite journal|last1=Laland|first1=KN|last2=Sterelny|first2=K|last3=Odling-Smee|first3=FJ|last4=Hoppitt|first4=W|last5=Uller|first5=T|title=Cause and effect in biology revisited: is Mayr’s proximate–ultimate dichotomy still useful?|journal=Science|date=2011|volume=334|pages=1512-1516|bibcode=2011Sci...334.1512L|doi=10.1126/science.1210879}}{{cite journal|last1=Laland|first1=KN|last2=Odling-Smee|first2=FJ|last3=Hoppitt|first3=W|last4=Uller|first4=T|title=More on how and why: cause and effect in biology revisited|journal=Biol Philos|date=2013|volume=28|pages=719-745}}{{cite journal|last1=Laland|first1=KN|last2=Odling-Smee|first2=FJ|last3=Hoppitt|first3=W|last4=Uller|first4=T|title=More on how and why: a response to commentaries|journal=Biol Philos|date=2013|volume=28|pages=793-810}} Formally, reciprocal causation exists when process A is a cause of process B and, subsequently, process B is a cause of process A, with this feedback potentially repeated. Some researchers, particularly advocates of the [[extended evolutionary synthesis]], promote the view that causation in biological systems is inherently reciprocal.{{cite journal|last1=Laland|first1=KN|last2=Uller|first2=T|last3=Feldman|first3=MW|last4=Sterelny|first4=K|last5=Müller|first5=GB|last6=Moczek|first6=A|last7=Jablonka|first7=E|last8=Odling-Smee|first8=FJ|title=The extended evolutionary synthesis: its structure, assumptions and predictions|journal=Proc R Soc B|date=2015|volume=282|page=20151019}} ==History== Harvard evolutionary biologist [[Ernst Mayr]] (1961){{cite journal|last1=Mayr|first1=E|title=Cause and effect in biology|journal=Science|date=1961|volume=134|pages=1501-1506|bibcode=1961Sci...134.1501M|doi=10.1126/science.134.3489.1501}} suggested that there are two fundamentally different types of causation in biology, [[Proximate and ultimate causation|‘ultimate’ and ‘proximate’]]. Ultimate causes (e.g. [[natural selection]]) were seen as (i) providing historical accounts for the existence of an organism’s features, and (ii) explaining the function or ‘goal-directedness’ of living beings. In contrast, proximate causes (e.g. [[physiology]]) were seen as explaining how biological systems work. According to Mayr, the evolutionary sciences study ultimate causes and the rest of biology studies proximate causes. In some of his works, Mayr considered these domains autonomous:

“The clarification of the biochemical mechanism by which the genetic program is translated into the phenotype tells us absolutely nothing about the steps by which natural selection has built up the particular genetic program.”

Mayr, 1980{{cite book|last1=Mayr|first1=E|editor1-last=Mayr|editor1-first=E|editor2-last=Provine|editor2-first=WB|title=The Evolutionary Synthesis|date=1980|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, USA|pages=1-48|chapter=Some thoughts on the history of the evolutionary synthesis}}

There has been widespread acceptance of the proximate-ultimate [[dichotomy]] within the evolutionary sciences. However, many biologists, psychologists and philosophers have taken issue with Mayr’s corollary that the [[Proximate and ultimate causation|proximate-ultimate distinction]] implies that development is irrelevant to evolution. For instance, evolutionary biologist Mary Jane West-Eberhard writes:

“The proximate-ultimate distinction has given rise to a new confusion, namely, a belief that proximate causes of phenotypic variation have nothing to do with ultimate, evolutionary explanation.”

West-Eberhard, 2003

Mayr’s position implied a unidirectional or linear conception of causation for both development and evolution: [[genotypes]] cause [[phenotypes]] (proximate causation), whilst through natural selection, changes in [[Environment (biophysical)|environments]] cause changes in [[organisms]] (ultimate causation). Reciprocal causation was proposed as an alternative to this linear characterization. (see also {{cite book|last1=Waddington|first1=CH|title=The Strategy of the Genes|date=1957|publisher=Routledge}}{{cite journal|last1=Dewsbury|first1=D|title=The proximate and the ultimate: past, present, and future|journal=Behav Process|date=1999|volume=46|pages=189-199}}{{cite journal|last1=Thierry|first1=B|title=Integrating proximate and ultimate causation: just one more go!|journal=Curr Sci|date=2005|volume=89|pages=1180-1183}}) It emphasizes how causation cycles through biological systems recursively, allowing proximate causes to feed back and thereby feature in ultimate explanations. ==Reciprocal causation in evolutionary biology== Reciprocal causation features in several explanations within contemporary [[evolutionary biology]], including [[sexual selection]] theory, [[coevolution]], habitat selection, and [[frequency-dependent selection]]. In these examples, the source of selection on a trait coevolves with the trait itself, therefore causation is reciprocal and developmental processes potentially become relevant to evolutionary accounts. For instance, a [[Peafowl|peacock]]’s tail evolves through mating preferences in peahens, and those preferences coevolve with the male trait. The ‘ultimate explanation’ for the male trait is the prior existence of female preferences, proximately manifest in differential peahen [[mate choice]] decisions, whilst the ‘ultimate explanation’ for the peahens’ mating preferences is the prior existence of variation in the peacock’s tail associated with fitness. This example illustrates how reciprocal causation is not a rejection of the proximate-ultimate distinction itself, but instead a rejection of the implication that developmental processes should not feature in evolutionary explanations. Reciprocal causation also applies in other domains of evolutionary biology. The [[extended evolutionary synthesis]] emphasizes how developmental events, including both the causal effects of environments on organisms (for instance, arising through developmental [[Phenotypic plasticity|plasticity]], or [[epigenetic inheritance]]) and the causal effects of organisms on environments (e.g. [[niche construction]]), can direct the course of evolution. Developmental plasticity, niche construction, extra-genetic forms of inheritance and developmental bias are recognized as playing evolutionary roles that cannot be reduced to [[natural selection]] of genetically encoded characters or strategies. Proximate causes are not autonomous from natural selection, but rather feed back to influence the rate and direction of [[adaptive evolution]]. This goes beyond the recognition that [[Ontogeny|ontogenetic processes]] can impose constraints on the action of selection, or that proximate and ultimate processes interact. Rather, developmental processes are also seen as a source of evolutionary novelty, initiators of evolutionary episodes, and co-directors of patterns of evolutionary change. ==Contention== Acceptance or rejection of Mayr’s proximate-ultimate distinction may lie at the centre of several major debates within contemporary biology, concerning [[Evolutionary developmental biology|evo devo (evolutionary developmental biology)]], [[niche construction]], [[cultural evolution]], human cooperation, and the [[Origin of language|evolution of language]]. According to some biologists and philosophers, these disputes share a common pattern. On one side are researchers who consider that interaction and feedback processes traditionally characterized as ‘proximate’ have explanatory value for ‘ultimate’ evolutionary questions.{{cite journal|last1=Laland|first1=KN|last2=Uller|first2=T|last3=Feldman|first3=MW|last4=Sterelny|first4=K|last5=Müller|first5=GB|last6=Moczek|first6=A|last7=Jablonka|first7=E|last8=Odling-Smee|first8=FJ|last9=Wray|first9=GA|last10=Hoekstra|first10=HE|last11=Futuyma|first11=DJ|last12=Lenski|first12=RE|last13=Mackay|first13=TFC|last14=Schluter|first14=D|last15=Strassmann|first15=JE|title=Does evolutionary theory need a rethink?|journal=Nature|date=2014|volume=514|pages=161-164|bibcode=2014Natur.514..161L|doi=10.1038/514161a}} Their concern is that the proximate-ultimate distinction has discouraged consideration of the manner in which developmental processes can set the evolutionary agenda, for instance, by introducing innovations, channeling phenotypic variation, or initiating evolutionary episodes through modifying selection pressures. One the other side are researchers who largely adopt Mayr’s stance with a clean separation of proximate and ultimate causation. For the latter, a failure to respect Mayr’s dichotomy is considered a sign of confusing an evolutionary explanation with a mechanistic explanation.{{cite journal|last1=Dawkins|first1=R|title=Extended phenotype—but not too extended. A reply to Laland, Turner and Jablonka|journal=Biol Physiol|date=2004|volume=19|pages=377-396}}{{cite journal|last1=De Jong|first1=G|title=Evolution of phenotypic plasticity: patterns of plasticity and the emergence of ecotypes|journal=New Phytol|date=2005|volume=166|pages=101-117}}{{cite journal|last1=West|first1=SA|last2=El Mouden|first2=C|last3=Gardner|first3=A|title=16 common misconceptions about the evolution of cooperation in humans|journal=Evol Hum Behav|date=2011|volume=32|pages=231-262}}{{cite journal|last1=Scott-Phillips|first1=T|last2=Dickins|first2=T|last3=West|first3=S|title=Evolutionary theory and the ultimate-proximate distinction in the human behavioural sciences|journal=Perspect Psychol Sci|date=2011|volume=6|pages=38-48}}{{cite journal|last1=Dickins|first1=TE|last2=Rahman|first2=Q|title=The extended evolutionary synthesis and the role of soft inheritance inevolution|journal=Proc R Soc B|date=2012|volume=279|pages=2913-2921}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Evolution]]

{{Redirect|Scholar|scholarly people|academic|and|intellectual|and|scientist|other uses}} {{confused|Scholasticism|Scholarism|Scholarship}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2008}} [[File:Gerbrand van den Eeckhout 003.jpg|thumb|260px|right|''Scholar and His Books'' by [[Gerbrand van den Eeckhout]].]] The '''scholarly method''' or '''scholarship''' is the body of [[principle]]s and [[Practice (social theory)|practice]]s used by [[wikt:scholar|scholars]] to make their claims about the world as valid and trustworthy as possible, and to make them known to the scholarly public. It is the methods that systemically advance the [[teaching]], [[research]], and [[:wikt:practice|practice]] of a given scholarly or academic field of study through rigorous inquiry. Scholarship is noted by its significance to its particular profession{{huh|date=October 2018}}, and is creative, can be documented, can be replicated or elaborated, and can be and is [[peer-reviewed]] through various methods.<ref>[http://www.aacn.nche.edu/publications/position/defining-scholarship Aacn.nche.edu, Retrieved 15OCT2012]</ref>
==Methods== Originally started to reconcile the [[philosophy]] of the ancient [[classical philosophy|classical philosophers]] with medieval [[Christian theology|theology]], [[scholasticism]] is not a philosophy or theology in itself but a tool and method for learning which places emphasis on [[dialectical reasoning]]. The primary purpose of scholasticism is to find the answer to a question or to resolve a contradiction. It was once well known for its application in medieval theology but was eventually applied to classical philosophy and many other fields of study.
The [[historical method]] comprises the techniques and guidelines by which [[historian]]s use [[primary source]]s and other evidence to research and then to [[historiography|write history]]. The question of the nature, and indeed the possibility, of sound historical method is raised in the [[philosophy of history]], as a question of [[epistemology]]. History guidelines commonly used by historians in their work require [[external criticism]], internal criticism, and [[Thesis, antithesis, synthesis|synthesis]].
The [[empirical method]] is generally taken to mean the collection of data on which to base a [[hypothesis]] or derive a conclusion in [[science]]. It is part of the [[scientific method]], but is often mistakenly assumed to be synonymous with other methods. The empirical method is not sharply defined and is often contrasted with the precision of experiments, where data is derived from the systematic manipulation of variables. The [[experimental method]] investigates [[causality|causal]] relationships among [[variable (mathematics)|variables]]. An experiment is a cornerstone of the [[empiricism|empirical]] approach to acquiring data about the world and is used in both [[natural science]]s and [[social science]]s. An experiment can be used to help solve practical problems and to support or negate [[theory|theoretical]] assumptions.
The scientific method refers to a body of techniques for investigating [[phenomenon|phenomena]], acquiring new [[knowledge]], or correcting and integrating previous knowledge. To be termed scientific, a method of [[inquiry]] must be based on gathering [[observable]], [[empirical]] and measurable [[evidence]] subject to specific principles of [[reasoning]].<ref>"[4] Rules for the study of [[natural philosophy]]", {{harvnb|Newton|1999|pp=794–6}}, Christian Horsley from the General Scholium, which follows Book '''3''', ''The System of the World''.</ref> A scientific method consists of the collection of [[data]] through [[observation]] and [[experiment]]ation, and the formulation and testing of [[hypotheses]].<ref> [http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/scientific%20method Merriam-Webster|Merriam-Webster Dictionary]</ref>
==See also== {{wikiquote|Scholarship}} {{Wiktionary|scholar|scholarly|scholarship}} {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Academia]] *[[Academic authorship]] *[[Academic publishing]] *[[Discipline (academia)]] *[[Doctor (title)]] *[[Historical revisionism]] *[[History of scholarship]] *[[Manual of style]] *[[Professor]] *[[Research]] *[[Rigour]] *[[Source criticism]] *[[Urtext edition]] {{div col end}}

Gardaí eventually conceded the road was private property.]]
'''Shell to Sea''' ({{lang-ga|Shell chun Sáile}}) is an Irish organisation based in the parish of [[Kilcommon]] in [[Erris]], [[County Mayo]].
It opposes the proposed construction of a [[natural gas]] [[Gas pipeline|pipeline]] through the parish, as well as the ongoing construction—by [[Royal Dutch Shell]], [[Statoil]] and Vermilion Energy Trust—of a [[Oil refinery|refinery]] at [[Bellanaboy]] intended to refine the natural gas from the [[Corrib gas field]]. It proposes instead that the gas be refined at sea, rather than inland, as is done with Ireland's only other producing gas field off [[County Cork]]. Shell to Sea believes the proximity of a raw natural gas pipeline is a risk to local residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publicinquiry.ie/pdf/Accufacts_Report_Hi_res.pdf |title=Report |work=publicinquiry.ie |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061231193519/http://www.publicinquiry.ie/pdf/Accufacts_Report_Hi_res.pdf |archivedate=31 December 2006 |df= }}</ref>
The three stated aims of the campaign, as cited on its website, are that "Any exploitation of the Corrib gas field be done in a safe way that will not expose the local community in Erris to unnecessary health, safety and environmental risks", "To renegotiate the terms of the Great Oil and Gas Giveaway, which sees Ireland's 10 billion barrels of oil equivalent off the West Coast go directly to the oil companies, with the Irish State retaining a 0% share, no energy security of supply and only 25% tax on profits against which all costs can be deducted" and "To seek justice for the human rights abuses suffered by Shell to Sea campaigners due to their opposition to Shell's proposed inland refinery".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shelltosea.com/content/campaign-aims|title=Campaign Aims|work=Shell to Sea}}</ref>
Incidents of note include the 2005 jailing of the [[Rossport Five]] and the public outcry that followed,<ref name="publicinquiry1"/> the 2007 [[Goldman Environmental Prize]] received by [[Willie Corduff]] (one of the five), local fisherman Pat O'Donnell's laying of 800 crab pots at sea and [[Maura Harrington]]'s hunger strike against the [[Allseas]] pipe-laying ship ''[[Solitaire (ship)|Solitaire]]'' in 2008, an [[Willie Corduff#2009 alleged assault|alleged assault on Corduff]] in 2009 which was condemned by [[Desmond Tutu]],<ref>{{cite news|first=Áine|last=Ryan|url=http://www.mayonews.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=6575&Itemid=38|title=Archbishop Tutu speaks out on Corrib as seven are arrested: Nobel Peace Laureate and internationally renowned human rights activist, Archbishop Desmond Tutu has spoken out about the controversial Corrib gas controversy|newspaper=The Mayo News|date=11 May 2009|accessdate=11 May 2009}}</ref> the 2011 "rape tape" scandal when [[Gardaí]] (police) accidentally filmed themselves joking about the imagined rape of two female protestors after arresting them,<ref name="Corribgate scandal Gardaí caught on confiscated camcorder"/> and the reports of gifts of alcohol worth tens of thousands of euros from Shell to the Gardaí, which broke in 2013.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/10/shell-pipeline-protests-county-mayo</ref>
==Timeline== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Shell to Sea banner in Belmullet.jpg|thumb|Shell to Sea banner, [[Belmullet]], January 2009]] --> {{Main article|Corrib gas controversy}} Opposition to the gas consortium and [[Irish government|government]]'s plans among local residents grew from 2000 when local residents felt they were not adequately consulted. They opposed planning permission and appealed it to [[An Bord Pleanála]] twice. It was felt that government pressure was used to force the planning permission through. They also felt misled about the safety of the gas pipeline which did not require planning permission under the 1976 Gas Act.<ref name="publicinquiry1">{{cite web|url=http://www.publicinquiry.ie/pdf/Fiosru_2_HI_RES_Final.pdf |title=FIOSRU - November 9 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2009-07-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061229225619/http://www.publicinquiry.ie/pdf/Fiosru_2_HI_RES_Final.pdf |archivedate=29 December 2006 |df= }}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Fence destruction in Glengad.jpg|thumb|Shell to Sea protesters destroy a section of fence around the Shell compound, [[Glengad]] beach, September 2008]] -->
===2005=== The first event organised by Shell to Sea was on the June Bank Holiday weekend in 2005 in support of [[Rossport]] residents' protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.anphoblacht.com/news/detail/9761|title=Shell's assault on Erris}}</ref>
Local landowners in Rossport had previously been told that the raw gas pipeline would be coming through their lands no matter what, and that they would be subject to [[Compulsory Purchase Order|Compulsory Acquisition Orders]] if unwilling to reach a deal with Shell.<ref name="publicinquiry1"/> Some<ref name="publicinquiry1"/> agreed to allow Shell on their lands. Others refused, and [[Frank Fahey]], then [[Minister for Communications, Energy and Natural Resources|Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources]] signed 34 Compulsory Acquisition Orders. Those who had refused were threatened with legal action. Legal action was taken which eventually culminated in four farmers and their former teacher, who had joined them in blocking Shell workers coming on their lands, being jailed on 29 June for civil [[contempt of court]] (at the request of Shell) after refusing to give an undertaking not to interfere with Shell's workers. They became known as the [[Rossport Five]].
24-hour pickets on the Shell sites at Rossport, Bellanaboy and [[Glengad]] began after their jailing.<ref name="publicinquiry1"/> Rallies in support of the men's stance were held in major towns and cities, and Shell and Statoil filling stations were picketed.<ref name="publicinquiry1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.anphoblacht.com/news/detail/10589|title=Campaign grows across Ireland|newspaper=An Phoblacht|accessdate=19 July 2009}}</ref> From these protests emerged the national Shell to Sea campaign.
The Rossport Five were released on 30 September, after their imprisonment had dominated proceedings in the parliament. [[Peter Cassells]] was appointed as a negotiator to arbitrate between the campaigners and Shell. As his remit did not include discussing the refinery, he was regarded as a distraction by Shell to Sea. The pickets at Bellanaboy continued for over a year, during which no work was done by Shell.
===2006=== On Tuesday 26 September 2006, protesters prevented Shell's employees from entering the site of the intended refinery at Bellanaboy to begin work. Around 150 locals and protesters blocked the entrance to the refinery site and began to recite the [[rosary]]. The workers turned back{{citation needed|date=September 2007}} after discussions with [[Garda Síochána|Gardaí]].{{citation needed|date=September 2007}}
One week later on 3 October, more Gardaí were brought in from around the country, which increased their numbers to around 170. This marked a departure in Garda tactics which they have held to. An editorial in ''[[The Irish Times]]'' stated: ''"The Garda [[baton charge]]s that occurred on Friday morning in Bellanaboy were not the product of Sinn Féin or [[Provisional IRA]] machinations; they were the product of abject Government incompetence."''<ref>''The Irish Times'', 26 November 2006.</ref> A decision to avoid arresting protesters in order to damp down the negative publicity that would ensue was discussed in the Garda magazine, ''Garda Review''. A number of people were injured and one young woman was brought to hospital.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mayonews.ie/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=420&Itemid=38l|title=Shell enter Bellanaboy site: Up to 170 Gardaí facilitated the entry of Shell workers to the Bellanaboy terminal site|publisher=Mayonews.ie|date=3 October 2006|accessdate=3 October 2006}}</ref>
Protesters occupied [[Shell Ireland]] HQ in [[Dublin]]'s [[Leeson Street]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1011/corrib.html|title=Protest continues in Co Mayo|work=[[RTÉ News]]|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=11 October 2006|accessdate=11 October 2006}}</ref> and daily protests continued at Bellanaboy with some arrests made.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1012/corrib.html|title=Sit-down protests at entrance to Corrib gas terminal site at Bellanaboy|work=[[RTÉ News]]|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=12 October 2006|accessdate=12 October 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Jim|last=Fahy|authorlink=Jim Fahy|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1020/morningireland.html|title=Shell to Sea in day of action at gas terminal site|work=[[Morning Ireland]]|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=20 October 2006|accessdate=20 October 2006}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Shell to sea1.jpg|thumb|Protest at gate of intended [[refinery]] site, [[Bellanaboy]], September 2007]] -->
A second large scale protest march took place on 10 November, the anniversary of the execution of [[Ken Saro Wiwa]] and eight other anti-Shell activists in [[Nigeria]] in 1995. When protesters worked their way around Gardaí lines, clashes occurred, resulting in several injuries. Small groups of demonstrators who had been unable to get to the refinery attempted to blockade the nearby Lennon's quarry which supplies material for the construction of the site.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1110/mayo.html|title=Protestors block convoy of vehicles taking construction workers to Corrib gas site|work=[[RTÉ News]]|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=10 November 2006|accessdate=10 November 2006}}</ref>
There was political controversy in Ireland about the use of such force on a peaceful demonstration. [[Taoiseach]] [[Bertie Ahern]], leader of [[Fianna Fáil]], said in a statement that the [[Irish government]]'s position was clear in relation to the Corrib gas situation - that the negotiating is over and "that is it". In relation to the policing of the protests, he and the Opposition's [[Enda Kenny]], leader of [[Fine Gael]], would only reiterate that "the law must be obeyed".
A further large scale protest at Bellanaboy scheduled for 24 November was cancelled by the protesters for fear of further serious injuries from Gardaí.<ref name="breakingnews2006"/>
===2007=== On 5 June, five protesters chained themselves together{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} outside the [[Bord na Móna]] facility near [[Bangor Erris]] where Shell have been dumping the peat removed from Bellinaboy.
On 12 September, a protester charged with public order offences had her case dismissed in [[Belmullet]] because of conflicting Garda evidence. The judge dismissed most of the charges and sentenced the five protesters from June to community service for threatening and abusive behaviour. The judge also disclosed that she had received "hate mail".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.westernpeople.ie/news/story.asp?j=38192&cat=news|archive-url=https://archive.is/20090619151226/http://www.westernpeople.ie/news/story.asp?j=38192&cat=news|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 June 2009|title=''Western People'' article|publisher=Westernpeople.ie|date=20 September 2007|accessdate=20 September 2007}}</ref>
===2008=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Shell to Sea kayak training.jpg|thumb|right|Shell to Sea kayak training, [[Glengad]], August 2008]] --> In April 2008, a new group was set up by people formerly active in S2S. [[Pobal Chill Chomáin]] proposed moving the refinery to Glinsk, which would have removed the necessity to transport the gas near people's homes and under roads. The proposal was rejected by both Shell{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} and the government.{{citation needed|date=September 2008}}
In 2008, a new security firm, [[Integrated Risk Management Services]], was brought in{{by whom|date=February 2013}} to defend Shell's preparations for the landfall of the raw gas pipeline. In August, S2S began training for marine protests in anticipation of the arrival of the [[Allseas]] pipe-laying ship ''[[Solitaire (ship)|Solitaire]]'', the biggest of its kind in the world with a collection of small boats. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Iollan's "arrest".jpg|thumb|Iollan Ó'Mongáin, son of [[Maura Harrington]], is detained by four Gardaí in September 2008. A Shell security guard tapes the detention.]] -->
In the meantime, a local Porturlin fisherman, Pat O'Donnell, laid 800 crab pots along the intended path of ''Solitaire'', and defended them from Shell survey boats which attempted to remove them. The [[Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine|Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food]] stated that as both parties had licenses for their activities, they would have to sort it out between themselves. Two [[Irish Navy]] ships arrived in Broadhaven Bay to assist the [[Garda Water Unit]] in dealing with the protests. ''Solitaire'' was boarded by S2S activists in [[Killybegs]]. Not long after it arrived to Mayo's coast, the ship's company said it had suffered damage to its crane. It returned to Britain for repairs. [[Maura Harrington]] began a [[hunger strike]] to coincide with the arrival of ''Solitaire'', the [[Allseas]] pipe-laying vessel, in [[Broadhaven Bay]]. Harrington, who had recently retired as principal of the local Inver Primary School,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/0910/breaking8.html?via=mr|title=Corrib work suspended for 'technical' reasons|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=10 September 2008|accessdate=10 September 2008}}</ref> continued her protest until the ship left Irish waters.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2008/0920/1221835126751.html|title=Shell to Sea protester ends 10-day hunger strike|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=20 September 2008|accessdate=20 September 2008}}</ref>
===2009=== In March 2009, Maura Harrington was sentenced to a month in [[Mountjoy Prison]], for assaulting a Garda at McGrath's pier. In July 2009, Niall Harnett and Maura Harrington, two leading Corrib gas activists were jailed for four months over demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0730/breaking77.htm|title=Two Shell protesters jailed|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5iGye_GC-ITa9Lpf35__SCt7lrc0A|title=Gas pipeline protesters jailed|work=[[The Press Association]]}}</ref>
In November 2009, the Garda Ombudsman Commission recommended that disciplinary action be taken against a senior member of An Garda Síochána over the handling of the June 2007 protest.{{citation needed|date=February 2010}} In a separate development, An Bord Pleanála found that up to half of the final section of Shell's proposed route for the onshore pipeline was ‘unacceptable’ on safety grounds.{{citation needed|date=February 2010}}
===2010=== Shell failed to meet An Bord Pleanala's deadline in February and applied for an extension of time to put their proposals forward as to how the project might proceed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0201/1224263502431.html|title=Shell asks for more time to resolve Corrib gas issues|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=1 February 2010|accessdate=1 February 2010}}</ref> Pat O'Donnell, from [[Kilcommon|Porturlin]], was sentenced to seven months imprisonment in February.<ref name="irishtimes.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0218/1224264714612.html|title=Shell confirms key parts of Corrib gas project postponed|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=18 February 2010|accessdate=18 February 2010}}</ref> In April, Niall Harnett of [[Kilcommon]], was jailed. Little work was carried out by Shell in 2010.<ref name="irishtimes.com"/> The film ''Pipe Down'' was a winner in the Waterford Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vimeo.com/8668733|title=Pipe Down}}</ref>
Brian Barrington BL in a report commissioned for [[Front Line Defenders]] found serious problems in North Mayo.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0427/1224269159758.html|title=Frontline report: Main points|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=27 April 2010|accessdate=27 April 2010}}</ref> On Monday 31 May 2010, Shell submitted a third revised EIS to An Bord Pleanala for a revised pipeline route.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lorna|last=Siggins|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0602/1224271675717.html|title=Planning board to assess latest Corrib plan|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=2 June 2010|accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
===2011=== In April 2011, it emerged that Gardaí who had just arrested two female protestors had made explicit jokes about raping them.<ref name="Corribgate scandal Gardaí caught on confiscated camcorder">{{cite news|first=Áine|last=Ryan|url=http://www.mayonews.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12344:gardai-in-corribgate-scandal&catid=23:news&Itemid=46|title=Gardaí in Corribgate scandal: Corrib Gardaí caught on confiscated camcorder: Investigation under way after ‘rape’ comments found on protestor's tape|newspaper=The Mayo News|date=5 April 2011|accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref> They had inadvertently recorded themselves making the comments on a video camera they had taken from one of the women, which they later returned with the recording on it. The comments were widely criticised. In December the Broadcasting Authority of Ireland upheld a complaint about RTÉ's television reporting of the Garda Síochána Ombudsman Commission's interim report. The report confirmed that the tape had recorded Gardaí joking about raping the women. The interim report found no evidence of a criminal offence having been committed by Gardaí and no evidence of a breach of discipline. The complaint, which was upheld, stated that RTÉ's report was inaccurate, lacked fairness, objectivity and impartiality and caused the woman involved undue harm and offence.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lorna|last=Siggins|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2011/1203/1224308523089.html|title=RTÉ report on Corrib tape breached 'fairness'|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=3 December 2011|accessdate=3 December 2011}}</ref>
Direct actions continued to hamper construction activities throughout 2011 and 2012. In May, 30 to 35 sections of wooden bog road were removed from their positions in the Shell site at Aughoose in a mass direct action by protestors. In June, between 400 and 500 people attended the ''Party Against the Pipe'' near the Shell compound in Aughoose, a family friendly gathering with craft workshops, music and food to mark the tenth anniversary of resistance to Shell's activities in Erris.<ref>{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Flood|url=http://www.wsm.ie/c/hundreds-gather-erris-party-against-pipe|title=Hundreds gather in Erris for the Party Against the Pipe|publisher=[[Workers Solidarity Movement]]|date=8 June 2011|accessdate=8 June 2011}}</ref> Direct actions continued to hamper construction activities throughout 2011, 2012 and 2013.
===2012=== Another gathering took place over the June bank holiday weekend. In July, Shell attempted to transport the tunnel boring machine from Dubin Port to Ballinaboy, but were met by many direct actions. Close to the compound, the oversize transport lorry drove off the road and remained stuck in the bog for several days. There were several arrests and assaults of protestors.<ref>{{cite news|first=Aine|last=Ryan|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/0802/breaking45.html|title=Shell machine remains stuck|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=2 August 2012|accessdate=2 August 2012}}</ref>
In September, Shell to Sea launched a new report on the location of Ireland's oil and gas reserves, which depicted all the areas of oil and gas exploration, oil and gas discoveries and commercial fields for the first time on a single map, as well as publishing the license holding companies' estimates of how much each was worth. The report, entitled 'Liquid Assets: Ireland's oil and gas resources and how they could be managed for the people's benefit', was launched by [[Paul Murphy (Irish politician)|Paul Murphy]], Socialist Party MEP.<ref>{{cite news|first=Ann|last=O'Loughlin|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/world/reserving-expectations-207108.html|title=Will consumers miss out on potential oil and gas bonanza?|newspaper=[[Irish Examiner]]|publisher=[[Thomas Crosbie Holdings]]|date=11 September 2012|accessdate=11 September 2012}}</ref>
===2013=== In February 2013, with Shell having revealed 2012 profits of €19.6 billion, people blocked trucks on their way to the multinational corporation's tunnelling compound at Aughoose. Campaigner Terence Conway said: "These obscene profits announced by Shell this week come at the expense of communities and the environment where Shell operate". Campaigner Maura Harrington said: "The Government are still willing to force suffering on the people of Ireland through severe cutbacks, yet at the same time give our oil and gas away to multinational companies such as Shell, with no benefit to country. It is time for people to demand that this situation is changed."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/shell-to-sea-protesters-block-trucks-en-route-to-compound-583405.html|title=Shell to Sea protesters block trucks en route to compound|work=BreakingNews.ie|publisher=[[Thomas Crosbie Holdings]]|date=2 February 2013|accessdate=2 February 2013}}</ref>
==Rossport Solidarity Camp== [[File:Rossport Solidarity Camp.jpg|thumb|right|Rossport Solidarity Camp, [[Rossport]], February 2007]] The Rossport Solidarity Camp was originally set up on ‘Rossport 5’ Philip McGrath's land in early July 2005. The site of the camp was on the proposed pipeline route. Set up at the request of local people who sought outside support in their campaign against the gas project, it houses national and international activists. In Spring 2006, the camp was set up again close to the beach at Glengad near the ‘landfall’ for Shell's proposed pipeline. [[Mayo County Council]] evicted the camp and it closed in December 2007. Since then the "camp" has been organised from the Rossport Solidarity House in Pollathomas. On Saturday 16 August 2008, the camp was set up afresh with two large tents.<ref>{{cite news|first=Aoife|last=Finneran|url=http://www.herald.ie/opinion/dirty-war-what-really-is-going-on-at-the-battle-of-rossport-1479997.html|title=Dirty War: what really is going on at the battle of Rossport? - Opinion, Frontpage|work=Herald.ie|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|date=22 September 2008|accessdate=22 September 2008}}</ref> In August 2008, camp members picketed the Shell compound near the beach at Glengad.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/0730/breaking77.htm|title=Two Corrib gas protesters jailed|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=30 July 2009|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> It organises informational weekends etc. In the same month they organised a beach party weekend to highlight the Glengad beach landfall site.<ref>{{cite news|first=Toni|last=Bourke|url=http://www.advertiser.ie/mayo/article/1146|title=Reclaim Glendad Beach party this weekend|newspaper=Mayo Advertiser|publisher=Advertiser.ie|date=8 August 2008|accessdate=8 August 2008}}</ref> In June 2009, about 40 Gardaí were stationed below the Camp to prevent activists from accessing either the beach or the sea.<ref>{{cite news|author=O2 Ideas Room |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/tight-security-as--shell-pipelaying-ship-nears-land-1791515.html|title=Tight security as Shell pipe-laying ship nears land - National News, Frontpage|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|date=26 June 2009|accessdate=2010-10-02}}</ref>
==Motivation== [[File:Shell to Sea mural.jpg|thumb|Shell to Sea [[mural]] on a [[gable]] by the [[Glenamoy]] River]] The campaign has a diverse support base,{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} including people from many political backgrounds{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} and those with no strong politics at all.{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} Local campaigners include former Fianna Fáil and [[Fine Gael]] supporters. Philip McGrath, one of the Rossport Five, was an election agent for Fine Gael leader [[Enda Kenny]]. [[Werner Blau]], a [[physics]] professor at [[Trinity College, Dublin]], and part-time Rossport resident, told his neighbours that the pipeline intended for Rossport would not even comply with [[United States]] standards, which he described as "pretty lax".<ref>{{cite news|first=Angelique|last=Chrisafis, Ireland correspondent|url=https://www.theguardian.com/international/story/0,,1530695,00.html|title=Jailing of Irish villagers sparks anger as farmers defy Shell in Battle of the Bog: Support swells for opponents of gas pipeline imprisoned for contempt of court|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London|date=18 July 2005|accessdate=18 July 2005}}</ref> In its rankings of countries' facilitation of oil and gas companies, the [[World Bank]] rates Ireland in its highest, "very favourable" category,{{citation needed|date=September 2008}} along with [[Pakistan]] and [[Argentina]]. By comparison, Nigeria is rated average. Mike Cunningham, a former director of Statoil, said: ''"No country in the world gives as favourable terms to the oil companies as Ireland."'' This is a result of legislation created by [[Ray Burke (Irish politician)|Ray Burke]], who served as Minister of Communications and Energy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/0124/burker.html|title=Burke starts sentence in Arbour Hill|work=[[RTÉ News]]|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|date=24 January 2005|accessdate=24 January 2005}}</ref>
Many<ref>{{cite web|title=Nuacht RTÉ/TNS mrbi Poll|publisher=[[RTÉ]] & TNS mrbi|date=September 2006|url=http://www.corribsos.com/uploads/nuachtmayopollrossport%5B1%5D.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2009-06-13}}</ref> people from outside [[Erris]] are concerned about aspects of the proposed project leading to widespread opposition. Some specific concerns are use of compulsory orders to acquire property for private companies and over-generous terms given to the oil companies by successive Fianna Fáil governments.<ref>{{cite news|first=Kevin|last=Sullivan|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/09/24/AR2005092401403.html|title=Protest Stalls Energy Giant in Rural Ireland|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[The Washington Post Company]]|date=25 September 2005|accessdate=25 September 2005}}</ref>
People from the [[Niger Delta]] now resident in Ireland have expressed support.{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} A mural of [[Ken Saro-Wiwa]], who was executed after leading a campaign to reduce Shell's influence in [[Ogoniland]], has been painted on a gable in Rossport and a memorial to the [[Ogoni Nine]] erected.
In 2006, Shell were accused of trying to influence local business, when the owner of a local adventure centre alleged that Shell offered him €15,000 in return for his support for the construction of the pipeline in 2005. Shell said in response, that at no point was such an offer made as it was against their business principles but that Shell had given a donation of €150 to a [[windsurfing]] festival following a request by the businessman.<ref>{{cite news|first=Brian|last=McDonald|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/shell-offered-to-pay-15000-for-support-73717.html|title=Shell 'offered to pay €15,000' for support|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|date=17 October 2006|accessdate=17 October 2006}}</ref>
==Criticism== Unsubstantiated allegations abound linking the [[List of organisations known as the Irish Republican Army|IRA]] and [[Sinn Féin]] to the Shell to Sea campaign.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lorna|last=Siggins|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/weekend/2010/1002/1224280153915.html|title=The Battle for Ballinaboy|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irishtimes.com|date=2 October 2010|accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref> In 2005, [[Michael McDowell (politician)|Michael McDowell]]—using [[Parliamentary privilege|Dáil privilege]]—claimed that Frank Connolly, an investigative journalist and a brother of one of the [[Colombia Three]], had travelled to [[Colombia]] under a false passport.<ref name=cpi-funding> {{cite news |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/1207/connollyf.html |title=US backer withdraws funding for CPI |work=[[RTÉ News]] |date=7 December 2005 }}</ref> McDowell subsequently leaked the alleged faked passport application to a friend, the journalist Sam Smyth of the ''[[Irish Independent]]'',<ref name=connolly-passport> {{cite news |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2005/1212/connollyf.html |title=McDowell says he gave papers to Independent |work=[[RTÉ News]] |date=12 December 2005 }}</ref> and prejudiced any potential Garda investigation. Although Connolly denied McDowell's accusations, the controversy led to [[Irish American]] private donor [[Chuck Feeney]] withdrawing funding from the [[Centre for Public Inquiry]], an investigative organisation which of which Frank Connolly was the director had published a report on the Corrib Gas Project, embarrassing the government.<ref name=cpi-funding/>
Stories of infiltration by political activists from outside the area and intimidation of project supporters had also been rife, but these were denied by the then independent [[Teachta Dála|TD]] [[Jerry Cowley]] and local Fine Gael [[Teachta Dála|TD]] [[Michael Ring]].<ref name="breakingnews2006">{{cite news|author=21/11/2006 - 16:12:21|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/shell-to-sea-campaign-gets-cross-party-support-286033.html |title='Shell to Sea' campaign gets cross-party support|publisher=BreakingNews.ie|date=21 November 2006|accessdate=21 November 2006}}</ref> Ring originally supported S2S, though later changed his position.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Workplace bullying]]|url=http://www.unison.ie/irish_independent/stories.php3?ca=9&si=1710340&issue_id=14795|title=Irish Independent|publisher=Unison.ie|date=21 October 2006|accessdate=21 October 2006}}</ref> Gardaí also made allegations of intimidation, though no arrests were made or individuals questioned. The president of [[Belmullet]] [[chamber of commerce]] told the media that what was described as "intimidation" is actually [[boycott]]ing of pro-Shell businesses by S2S supporters. He told ''[[The Irish Times]]'': "It has never been anything more serious than that, but that is serious enough."<ref>"Erris will never be the same again", ''The Irish Times'', 27 November 2006.</ref>

{{lowercase title}} In the branch of [[mathematics]] called [[homological algebra]], a '''''t''-structure''' is a way to axiomatize the properties of an [[abelian category|abelian subcategory]] of a [[derived category]]. A ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}</math> consists of two subcategories <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> of a [[triangulated category]] or stable [[infinity category]] which abstract the idea of complexes whose cohomology vanishes in positive, respectively negative, degrees. There can be many distinct ''t''-structures on the same category, and the interplay between these structures has implications for algebra and geometry. The notion of a ''t''-structure arose in the work of Beilinson, Bernstein, Deligne, and Gabber on [[perverse sheaf|perverse sheaves]].<ref>Beĭlinson, A. A.; Bernstein, J.; Deligne, P. ''Faisceaux pervers.'' Analysis and topology on singular spaces, I (Luminy, 1981), 5–171, Astérisque, 100, Soc. Math. France, Paris, 1982.</ref>
==Definition== Fix a triangulated category <math>\mathcal{D}</math> with translation functor <math>[1]</math>. A '''''t''-structure''' on <math>\mathcal{D}</math> is a pair <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> of full subcategories, each of which is stable under isomorphism, which satisfy the following three axioms. # If ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>, then <math>\operatorname{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(X, Y[-1]) = 0.</math> # If ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math>, then ''X''[1] is also an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math>. Similarly, if ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>, then ''Y''[-1] is also an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>. # If ''A'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, then there exists a distinguished triangle <math>X \to A \to Y[-1] \to X[1]</math> such that ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>. It can be shown that the subcategories <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math> are closed under extensions in <math>\mathcal{D}</math>. In particular, they are stable under finite direct sums.
If <math>\mathcal{D}</math> is a stable ∞-category, then a '''''t''-structure''' on <math>\mathcal{D}</math> is defined to be a ''t''-structure on its homotopy category <math>\mathrm{h}\mathcal{D}</math> (which is a triangulated category).
Suppose that <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> is a ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}</math> (either a triangulated category or a stable ∞-category). In this case, for any integer ''n'', we define <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le n}</math> to be the full subcategory of <math>\mathcal{D}</math> whose objects have the form <math>X[-n]</math>, where <math>X</math> is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math>. Similarly, <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge n}</math> is the full subcategory of objects <math>Y[-n]</math>, where <math>Y</math> is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>. More briefly, we define :<math>\begin{align} \mathcal{D}^{\le n} &= \mathcal{D}^{\le 0}[-n], \\ \mathcal{D}^{\ge n} &= \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}[-n]. \end{align}</math> With this notation, the axioms above may be rewritten as: # If ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math>, then <math>\operatorname{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(X, Y) = 0.</math> # <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0} \subseteq \mathcal{D}^{\le 1}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0} \supseteq \mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math>. # If ''A'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, then there exists a distinguished triangle <math>X \to A \to Y \to X[1]</math> such that ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math>.
The '''heart''' or '''core''' of the ''t''-structure is the full subcategory <math>\mathcal{D}^\heartsuit</math> consisting of objects in both <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>, that is, :<math>\mathcal{D}^\heartsuit = \mathcal{D}^{\le 0} \cap \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}.</math> The heart of a ''t''-structure is an [[abelian category]] (whereas a triangulated category is additive but almost never abelian), and it is stable under extensions.
A triangulated or stable ∞-category with a choice of ''t''-structure is sometimes called a '''''t''-category'''.
===Variations=== It is clear that, to define a ''t''-structure, it suffices to fix integers ''m'' and ''n'' and specify <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le m}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge n}</math>. Some authors define a ''t''-structure to be the pair <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 1})</math>.
The two subcategories <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math> determine each other. An object ''X'' is in <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> if and only if <math>\operatorname{Hom}(X, Y) = 0</math> for all objects ''Y'' in <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math>, and vice versa. That is, <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 1})</math> are left and right orthogonal complements of each other. Consequently it is enough to specify only one of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math>.
The above notation is adapted to the study of cohomology. When the goal is to study homology, slightly different notation is used. A '''homological ''t''-structure''' on <math>\mathcal{D}</math> is a pair <math>(\mathcal{D}_{\ge 0}, \mathcal{D}_{\le 0})</math> such that, if we define :<math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}) = (\mathcal{D}_{\ge 0}, \mathcal{D}_{\le 0}),</math> then <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> is a (cohomological) ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}</math>. That is, the definition is the same except that upper indices are converted to lower indices and the roles of <math>\ge</math> and <math>\le</math> are swapped. If we define :<math>\begin{align} \mathcal{D}_{\ge n} &= \mathcal{D}_{\ge 0}[n], \\ \mathcal{D}_{\le n} &= \mathcal{D}_{\le 0}[n], \end{align}</math> then the axioms for a homological ''t''-structure may be written explicitly as # If ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}_{\ge 0}</math> and ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}_{\le -1}</math>, then <math>\operatorname{Hom}_{\mathcal{D}}(X, Y) = 0.</math> # <math>\mathcal{D}_{\ge 1} \subseteq \mathcal{D}_{\ge 0}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}_{\le 1} \supseteq \mathcal{D}_{\le 0}</math>. # If ''A'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, then there exists a distinguished triangle <math>X \to A \to Y \to X[1]</math> such that ''X'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}_{\ge 0}</math> and ''Y'' is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}_{\le -1}</math>.
==Examples== ===The natural ''t''-structure=== The most fundamental example of a ''t''-structure is the '''natural ''t''-structure''' on a derived category. Let <math>\mathcal{A}</math> be an abelian category, and let <math>D(\mathcal{A})</math> be its derived category. Then the natural ''t''-structure is defined by the pair of subcategories :<math>\begin{align} D(\mathcal{A})^{\le 0} &= \{X \colon \forall i > 0,\ H^i(X) = 0\}, \\ D(\mathcal{A})^{\ge 0} &= \{X \colon \forall i < 0,\ H^i(X) = 0\}. \end{align}</math> It follows immediately that :<math>\begin{align} D(\mathcal{A})^{\le n} &= \{X \colon \forall i > n,\ H^i(X) = 0\}, \\ D(\mathcal{A})^{\ge n} &= \{X \colon \forall i < n,\ H^i(X) = 0\}, \\ D(\mathcal{A})^\heartsuit &= \{X \colon \forall i \neq 0,\ H^i(X) = 0\} \cong \mathcal{A}. \end{align}</math> In this case, the third axiom for a ''t''-structure, the existence of a certain distinguished triangle, can be made explicit as follows. Suppose that <math>A^\bullet</math> is a cochain complex with values in <math>\mathcal{A}</math>. Define :<math>\begin{align} \tau^{\le 0}A^\bullet &= (\cdots \to A^{-2} \to A^{-1} \to \ker d^0 \to 0 \to 0 \to \cdots), \\ \tau^{\ge 1}A^\bullet &= (\cdots \to 0 \to 0 \to A^0 / \ker d^0 \to A^1 \to A^2 \to \cdots). \end{align}</math> It is clear that <math>\tau^{\ge 1}A^\bullet = A^\bullet / \tau^{\le 0}A^\bullet</math> and that there is a short exact sequence of complexes :<math>0 \to \tau^{\le 0} A^\bullet \to A^\bullet \to \tau^{\ge 1} A^\bullet \to 0.</math> This exact sequence furnishes the required distinguished triangle.
This example can be generalized to exact categories (in the sense of Quillen).<ref>Beilinson, Bernstein, and Deligne, 1.3.22.</ref> There are also similar ''t''-structures for the bounded, bounded above, and bounded below derived categories. If <math>\mathcal{C}</math> is an abelian subcategory of <math>\mathcal{A}</math>, then the full subcategory <math>D_{\mathcal{C}}(\mathcal{A})</math> of <math>D(\mathcal{A})</math> consisting of those complexes whose cohomology is in <math>\mathcal{C}</math> has a similar ''t''-structure whose heart is <math>\mathcal{C}</math>.<ref>Beilinson, Bernstein, and Deligne, p. 13.</ref>
===Perverse sheaves=== The category of ''[[perverse sheaves]]'' is, by definition, the core of the so-called ''perverse t-structure'' on the derived category of the category of sheaves on a [[complex analytic space]] ''X'' or (working with l-adic sheaves) an [[algebraic variety]] over a finite field. As was explained above, the heart of the standard t-structure simply contains ordinary sheaves, regarded as complexes concentrated in degree 0. For example, the category of perverse sheaves on a (possibly singular) algebraic curve ''X'' (or analogously a possibly singular surface) is designed so that it contains, in particular, objects of the form :<math>i_* F_Z, j_* F_U[1]</math> where <math>i: Z \to X</math> is the inclusion of a point, <math>F_Z</math> is an ordinary sheaf, <math>U</math> is a smooth open subscheme and <math>F_U</math> is a locally constant sheaf on ''U''. Note the presence of the shift according to the dimension of ''Z'' and ''U'' respectively. This shift causes the category of perverse sheaves to be [[well-behaved]] on singular spaces. The simple objects in this category are the [[intersection cohomology]] sheaves of subvarieties with coefficients in an irreducible local system. This t-structure was introduced by Beilinson, Bernstein and Deligne.<ref>Beĭlinson, A. A.; Bernstein, J.; Deligne, P. ''Faisceaux pervers.'' Analysis and topology on singular spaces, I (Luminy, 1981), 5–171, Astérisque, 100, Soc. Math. France, Paris, 1982.</ref> It was shown by Beilinson that the derived category of the heart <math>D^b(Perv(X))</math> is in fact equivalent to the original derived category of sheaves. This is an example of the general fact that a triangulated category may be endowed with several distinct t-structures.<ref>Beĭlinson, A. A. ''On the derived category of perverse sheaves.'' K-theory, arithmetic and geometry (Moscow, 1984–1986), 27–41, Lecture Notes in Math., 1289, Springer, Berlin, 1987.</ref>
===Graded modules=== A non-standard example of a t-structure on the derived category of (graded) modules over a [[graded ring]] has the property that its heart consists of complexes :<math>\dots \to P^n \to P^{n+1} \to \dots</math> where <math>P^n</math> is a module generated by its (graded) degree ''n''. This t-structure called geometric t-structure plays a prominent role in [[Koszul duality]].<ref>Beilinson, Alexander; Ginzburg, Victor; Soergel, Wolfgang. ''Koszul duality patterns in representation theory.'' J. Amer. Math. Soc. 9 (1996), no. 2, 473–527.</ref>
===Spectra=== The category of [[spectrum (topology)|spectra]] is endowed with a t-structure generated, in the sense above, by a single object, namely the [[sphere spectrum]]. The category <math>Sp^{\le 0}</math> is the category of connective spectra, i.e., those whose negative [[homotopy group]]s vanish. (In areas related to homotopy theory, it is common to use homological conventions, as opposed to cohomological ones, so in this case it is common to replace "<math>\le</math>" by "<math>\ge</math>". Using this convention, the category of connective spectra the notation is denoted <math>Sp^{\ge 0}</math>.)
===Motives=== A conjectural example in the theory of [[motive (algebraic geometry)|motives]] is the so-called ''motivic t-structure''. Its (conjectural) existence is closely related to certain [[standard conjectures on algebraic cycles]] and vanishing conjectures, such as the [[Beilinson-Soulé conjecture]].<ref>Hanamura, Masaki. ''Mixed motives and algebraic cycles. III.'' Math. Res. Lett. 6 (1999), no. 1, 61–82.</ref>
==Truncation functors== In the above example of the natural ''t''-structure on an abelian category, the distinguished triangle guaranteed by the third axiom was constructed by truncation. As operations on the category of complexes, the truncations <math>\tau_{\le 0}A^\bullet</math> and <math>\tau_{\ge 1} A^\bullet</math> are functorial, and the resulting short exact sequence of complexes is natural in <math>A^\bullet</math>. Using this, it can be shown that there are truncation functors on the derived category and that they induce a natural distinguished triangle.
In fact, this is an example of a general phenomenon. While the axioms for a ''t''-structure do not assume the existence of truncation functors, such functors can always be constructed and are essentially unique. Suppose that <math>\mathcal{D}</math> is a triangulated category and that <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> is a ''t''-structure. The precise statement is that the inclusion functors :<math>\begin{align} \iota^{\le n} \colon &\mathcal{D}^{\le n} \to \mathcal{D}, \\ \iota^{\ge n} \colon &\mathcal{D}^{\ge n} \to \mathcal{D} \end{align}</math> admit [[adjoint functor|adjoints]]. These are functors :<math>\begin{align} \tau^{\le n} \colon &\mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{D}^{\le n}, \\ \tau^{\ge n} \colon &\mathcal{D} \to \mathcal{D}^{\ge n} \end{align}</math> such that :<math>\begin{align} \iota^{\le n} \dashv \tau^{\le n}, \\ \tau^{\ge n} \dashv \iota^{\ge n}. \end{align}</math> Moreover, for any object <math>A</math> of <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, there exists a unique :<math>d \in \operatorname{Hom}^1(\tau^{\ge 1} A, \tau^{\le 0} A)</math> such that ''d'' and the counit and unit of the adjunctions together define a distinguished triangle :<math>\tau^{\le 0} A \to A \to \tau^{\ge 1} A\ \stackrel{d}{\to}\ \tau^{\le 0} A[1].</math> Up to unique isomorphism, this is the unique distinguished triangle of the form <math>X \to A \to Y \to X[1]</math> with <math>X</math> and <math>Y</math> objects of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}</math>, respectively. It follows from the existence of this triangle that an object <math>A</math> lies in <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le n}</math> (resp. <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge n}</math>) if and only if <math>\tau^{\ge n+1}(A) = 0</math> (resp. <math>\tau^{\le n-1}(A) = 0</math>).
The existence of <math>\tau^{\le 0}</math> implies the existence of the other truncation functors by shifting and taking opposite categories. If <math>A</math> is an object of <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, the third axiom for a ''t''-structure asserts the existence of an <math>X</math> in <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> and a morphism <math>X \to A</math> fitting into a certain distinguished triangle. For each <math>A</math>, fix one such triangle and define <math>\tau^{\le 0}(A) = X</math>. The axioms for a ''t''-structure imply that, for any object <math>T</math> of <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math>, we have :<math>\operatorname{Hom}(T, X) \cong \operatorname{Hom}(T, A),</math> with the isomorphism being induced by the morphism <math>X \to A</math>. This exhibits <math>X</math> as a solution to a certain universal mapping problem. Standard results on adjoint functors now imply that <math>X</math> is unique up to unique isomorphism and that there is a unique way to define <math>\tau^{\le 0}</math> on morphisms that makes it a right adjoint. This proves the existence of <math>\tau^{\le 0}</math> and hence the existence of all the truncation functors.
Repeated truncation for a ''t''-structure behaves similarly to repeated truncation for complexes. If <math>n \le m</math>, then there are natural transformations :<math>\begin{align} \tau^{\le n} &\to \tau^{\le m}, \\ \tau^{\ge n} &\to \tau^{\ge m}, \end{align}</math> which yield natural equivalences :<math>\begin{align} \tau^{\le n}\ &\stackrel{\sim}{\to}\ \tau^{\le n} \circ \tau^{\le m}, \\ \tau^{\ge m}\ &\stackrel{\sim}{\to}\ \tau^{\ge m} \circ \tau^{\ge n}, \\ \tau^{\ge n} \circ \tau^{\le m} \ &\stackrel{\sim}{\to}\ \tau^{\le m} \circ \tau^{\ge n}. \end{align}</math>
==Cohomology functors== The ''n''th ''cohomology functor'' <math>H^n</math> is defined as :<math>H^n = \tau^{\le 0} \circ \tau^{\ge 0} \circ [n].</math> As the name suggests, this is a cohomological functor in the usual sense for a triangulated category. That is, for any distinguished triangle <math>X \to Y \to Z \to X[1]</math>, we obtain a [[long exact sequence]] :<math>\cdots \to H^i(X) \to H^i(Y) \to H^i(Z) \to H^{i + 1}(X) \to \cdots.</math> In applications to algebraic topology, the cohomology functors may be denoted <math>\pi_n</math> instead of <math>H^n</math>. The cohomology functors take values in the heart <math>\mathcal{D}^\heartsuit</math>.
For the natural ''t''-structure on a derived category <math>D(\mathcal{A})</math>, the cohomology functor <math>H^n</math> is, up to quasi-isomorphism, the usual ''n''th cohomology group of a complex. However, considered as functors on complexes, this is ''not'' true. Consider, for example, <math>H^0</math> as defined in terms of the natural ''t''-structure. By definition, this is :<math>\begin{align} H^0(A^\bullet) &= \tau^{\le 0}(\tau^{\ge 0}(A^\bullet)) \\ &= \tau^{\le 0}(\cdots \to 0 \to A^{-1} / \ker d^{-1} \to A^0 \to A^1 \to \cdots) \\ &= (\cdots \to 0 \to A^{-1} / \ker d^{-1} \to \ker d^0 \to 0 \to \cdots). \end{align}</math> This complex is non-zero in degrees <math>-1</math> and <math>0</math>, so it is clearly not the same as the zeroth cohomology group of the complex <math>A^\bullet</math>. However, the non-trivial differential is an injection, so the only non-trivial cohomology is in degree <math>0</math>, where it is <math>\ker d^0 / \operatorname{im} d^{-1}</math>, the zeroth cohomology group of the complex <math>A^\bullet</math>. It follows that the two possible definitions of <math>H^0(A^\bullet)</math> are quasi-isomorphic.
A ''t''-structure is '''non-degenerate''' if the intersection of all <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le n}</math>, as well as the intersection of all <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge n}</math>, consists only of zero objects. For a non-degenerate ''t''-structure, the collection of functors <math>\{H^n\}_{n \in \mathbf{Z}}</math> is conservative. Moreover, in this case, <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le n}</math> (resp. <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge n}</math>) may be identified with the full subcategory of those objects <math>A</math> for which <math>H^i(A) = 0</math> for <math>i > n</math> (resp. <math>i < n</math>).
==Exact functors== For <math>i = 1, 2</math>, let <math>\mathcal{D}_i</math> be a triangulated category with a fixed ''t''-structure <math>(\mathcal{D}_i^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}_i^{\ge 0})</math> Suppose that <math>F \colon \mathcal{D}_1 \to \mathcal{D}_2</math> is an exact functor (in the usual sense for triangulated categories, that is, up to a natural equivalence it commutes with translation and preserves distinguished triangles). Then <math>F</math> is: * '''Left ''t''-exact''' if <math>F(\mathcal{D}_1^{\ge 0}) \subseteq \mathcal{D}_2^{\ge 0}</math>, * '''Right ''t''-exact''' if <math>F(\mathcal{D}_1^{\le 0}) \subseteq \mathcal{D}_2^{\le 0}</math>, and * '''''t''-exact''' if it is both left and right ''t''-exact.
It is elementary to see that if <math>F</math> is fully faithful and ''t''-exact, then an object <math>A</math> of <math>\mathcal{D}_1</math> is in <math>\mathcal{D}_1^{\le 0}</math> (resp. <math>\mathcal{D}_1^{\ge 0}</math>) if and only if <math>FA</math> is in <math>\mathcal{D}_2^{\le 0}</math> (resp. <math>\mathcal{D}_2^{\ge 0}</math>). It is also elementary to see that if <math>G \colon \mathcal{D}_2 \to \mathcal{D}_3</math> is another left (resp. right) ''t''-exact functor, then the composite <math>G \circ F</math> is also left (resp. right) ''t''-exact.
The motivation for the study of one-sided ''t''-exactness properties is that they lead to one-sided exactness properties on hearts. Let <math>\iota_i^\heartsuit \colon \mathcal{D}_i^\heartsuit \to \mathcal{D}_i</math> be the inclusion. Then there is a composite functor :<math>{}^pF = H^0 \circ F \circ \iota_1^\heartsuit \colon \mathcal{D}_1^\heartsuit \to \mathcal{D}_2^\heartsuit.</math> It can be shown that if <math>F</math> is left (resp. right) exact, then <math>{}^pF</math> is also left (resp. right) exact, and that if <math>G</math> is also left (resp. right) exact, then <math>{}^p(G \circ F) = ({}^pG) \circ F</math>.
If <math>F</math> is left (resp. right) ''t''-exact, and if <math>A</math> is in <math>\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}</math> (resp. <math>\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0}</math>), then there is a natural isomorphism <math>{}^pF(H^0A)\ \stackrel{\sim}{\to}\ H^0F(A)</math> (resp. <math>H^0F(A)\ \stackrel{\sim}{\to}\ {}^pF(H^0A)</math>).
If <math>(T^*, T_*) \colon \mathcal{D}_1 \leftrightarrows \mathcal{D}_2</math> are exact functors with <math>T^*</math> left adjoint to <math>T_*</math>, then <math>T^*</math> is right ''t''-exact if and only if <math>T_*</math> is left ''t''-exact, and in this case, <math>({}^pT^*, {}^pT_*)</math> are a pair of adjoint functors <math>\mathcal{D}_1^\heartsuit \leftrightarrows \mathcal{D}_2^\heartsuit</math>.
==Constructions of ''t''-structures== Let <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> be a ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}</math>. If ''n'' is an integer, then the '''translation by ''n''''' ''t''-structure is <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le n}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge n})</math>. The '''dual ''t''-structure''' is the ''t''-structure on the [[opposite category]] <math>\mathcal{D}^\text{op}</math> defined by <math>((\mathcal{D}^{\le 0})^\text{op}, (\mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})^\text{op})</math>.
Let <math>\mathcal{D}'</math> be a triangulated subcategory of a triangulated category <math>\mathcal{D}</math>. If <math>(\mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> is a ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, then :<math>((\mathcal{D}')^{\le 0}, (\mathcal{D}')^{\ge 0}) = (\mathcal{D}' \cap \mathcal{D}^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}' \cap \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0})</math> is a ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}'</math> if and only if <math>\mathcal{D}'</math> is stable under the truncation functor <math>\tau^{\le 0}</math>. When this condition holds, the ''t''-structure <math>((\mathcal{D}')^{\le 0}, (\mathcal{D}')^{\ge 0})</math> is called the '''induced ''t''-structure'''. The truncation and cohomology functors for the induced ''t''-structure are the restriction to <math>\mathcal{D}'</math> of those on <math>\mathcal{D}</math>. Consequently the inclusion of <math>\mathcal{D}'</math> in <math>\mathcal{D}</math> is ''t''-exact, and <math>(\mathcal{D}')^\heartsuit = \mathcal{D}^\heartsuit \cap \mathcal{D}'</math>.
To construct the category of perverse sheaves, it is important to be able to define a ''t''-structure on a category of sheaves over a space by working locally in that space. The precise conditions necessary for this to be possible can be abstracted somewhat to the following setup. Suppose that there are three triangulated categories and two morphisms :<math>\mathcal{D}_F\ \stackrel{i_*}{\to}\ \mathcal{D}\ \stackrel{j^*}{\to}\ \mathcal{D}_U</math> satisfying the following properties. * There are two sequences of triples of adjoint functors <math>(j_!, j^*, j_*)</math> and <math>(i^*, i_*, i^!)</math>. * The functors <math>i_*</math>, <math>j_!</math>, and <math>j^*</math> are full and faithful, and they satisfy <math>j^*i_* = 0</math>. * There are unique differentials making, for every ''K'' in <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, exact triangles :<math>\begin{align} j_!j^*K &\to K \to i_*i^*K \to j_!j^*K[1], \\ i_*i^!K &\to K \to i_*i^*K \to i_*i^!K[1]. \end{align}</math> In this case, given ''t''-structures <math>(\mathcal{D}_U^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}_U^{\ge 0})</math> and <math>(\mathcal{D}_F^{\le 0}, \mathcal{D}_F^{\ge 0})</math> on <math>\mathcal{D}_U</math> and <math>\mathcal{D}_F</math>, respectively, there is a ''t''-structure on <math>\mathcal{D}</math> defined by :<math>\begin{align} \mathcal{D}^{\le 0} &= \{ K \in \mathcal{D} \colon j^*K \in \mathcal{D}_U^{\le 0},\ i^*K \in \mathcal{D}_F^{\le 0}\}, \\ \mathcal{D}^{\ge 0} &= \{ K \in \mathcal{D} \colon j^*K \in \mathcal{D}_U^{\ge 0},\ i^*K \in \mathcal{D}_F^{\ge 0}\}. \end{align}</math> This ''t''-structure is said to be the '''gluing''' of the ''t''-structures on ''U'' and ''F''. The intended use cases are when <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, <math>\mathcal{D}_U</math>, and <math>\mathcal{D}_F</math> are bounded below derived categories of sheaves on a space ''X'', an open subset ''U'', and the closed complement ''F'' of ''U''. The functors <math>j^*</math> and <math>i_*</math> are the usual pullback and pushforward functors. This works, in particular, when the sheaves in question are left modules over a sheaf of rings <math>\mathcal{O}</math> on ''X'' and when the sheaves are ℓ-adic sheaves.
Many t-structures arise by means of the following fact: in a triangulated category with arbitrary [[direct sum]]s, and a set <math>S_0</math> of [[compact object (category theory)|compact objects]] in <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, the subcategories :<math>\begin{align} \mathcal{D}^{\ge 1} &= \{X \in \mathcal{D} \colon \operatorname{Hom}(S_0[-n], X) = 0, n \ge 0\}, \\ \mathcal{D}^{\le 0} &= \{Y \in \mathcal{D} \colon \operatorname{Hom}(Y, \mathcal{D}^{\ge 1}) = 0\}, \end{align}</math> can be shown to be a t-structure.<ref>Beligiannis, Apostolos; Reiten, Idun. ''Homological and homotopical aspects of torsion theories.'' Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 188 (2007), no. 883, viii+207 pp. Theorem III.2.3</ref> The resulting ''t''-structure is said to be '''generated by <math>S_0</math>'''.
Given an abelian subcategory <math>\mathcal{C}</math> of a triangulated category <math>\mathcal{D}</math>, it is possible to construct a subcategory of <math>\mathcal{D}</math> and a ''t''-structure on that subcategory whose heart is <math>\mathcal{C}</math>.<ref>Beilinson, Bernstein, and Deligne, proposition 1.3.13.</ref>
==Related concepts== If the requirement <math>D^{\le 0}\subset D^{\le 1}</math>, <math>D^{\ge 1}\subset D^{\ge 0};</math> is replaced by the opposite inclusion :<math>D^{\le 0}\supset D^{\le 1}</math>, <math>D^{\ge 1}\supset D^{\ge 0},</math> and the other two axioms kept the same, the resulting notion is called a ''co-t-structure'' or ''weight structure''.<ref>Bondarko, M. V. ''Weight structures vs. t-structures; weight filtrations, spectral sequences, and complexes (for motives and in general).'' J. K-Theory 6 (2010), no. 3, 387–504.</ref>

'''Trading Blows'', or'' Trading licks'', or '''- blows, - shots'', etc., is an endurance test in which the participants (usually two [[boy]]s or young men) take turns, alternating between administering a blow to an opponent and assuming the agreed exposed position (e.g. bending over an object or grabbing the ankles) to endure the next one, using the same implement (e.g. a [[fraternity paddle]]), until only the winner can still bring himself to endure the gradually increasing pain in the progressively tormented target part of their anatomy (usually the posterior, in which case it is a form of [[spanking]], or the cheeks), which in the interest of fairness should be either bared or only covered by a common uniform. As the blows are not given by the same person but by the parties themselves, the strongest-armed one actually has an unfair (but not always decisive) physical advantage.
Such rather [[macho]] displays of willpower, restraining the instinct to avoid pain, can serve various purposes, including: *a [[physical punishment]], especially for quarreling, possibly the origin of the practice (this ritualized alternative to a more disabling or even lethal [[duel]] should also make its participants realize the futility of physical aggression) *a motivation test, especially as part of an initiation process, such as [[hazing]] *an obedience test, as in certain [[Paddle (spanking)|paddle game]]s (possibly really an excuse for the rather sadistic amusement of the seniors) *a duel, either personal or as champions representing similar, especially rivaling, groups; in certain fraternities, refusing such a challenge may result in exclusion from the membership, even for an alumnus *as a game, either to 'proudly' display one's tenacity (often to impress some audience) or in the pursuit of a sadist and/or masochistic, erotic or pain-addicted, kick. *as a [[sexual fetish]]
Another game with the same name is often played among boys or young men, where two people agree on a place to hit the other (e.g. the shoulder or chest) and the two take turns trading punches until one person cannot stand the pain any longer. The first person to give up is the loser.
==See also== *[[One-upmanship]]
==Sources and references== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050305105214/http://www.troop17.org/flashbk.htm game in a scout troop in St.Louis, Missouri in the 1950s- scroll to "the Baker paddle"]
